dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, big news in the markets today, huh? Like, a real turnaround it seems.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, big news in the markets today, huh? Like, a real turnaround it seems.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, totally, A! Massive surge! The Dow, uh, was up over 1,400 points by mid-afternoon. S&P 500, Nasdaq, all seeing significant gains.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, totally, A! Massive surge! The Dow, uh, was up over fourteen hundred points by mid-afternoon. S and P five hundred, Nasdaq, all seeing significant gains.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 5.2%, over 1,400 points, by mid-afternoon on Thursday, while the S&P 500 was down 4.2% and the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite lost 3.5%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. I mean, the S&P 500 is on track for its third straight day of gains, right? After briefly turning positive for the year, and then... not.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. I mean, the S and P five hundred is on track for its third straight day of gains, right? After briefly turning positive for the year, and then... not.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The S&P 500 is on track for a third straight day of losses, turning negative for the year after briefly turning positive for 2020 earlier this week.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly! And the Dow, it's set for its biggest single-day jump since, like, March. It's pretty wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly! And the Dow, it's set for its biggest single-day jump since, like, March. It's pretty wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Dow is set for its biggest single-day drop since March.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, what's driving all this, uh, sudden optimism? Is it the Fed?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, what's driving all this, uh, sudden optimism? Is it the Fed?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yep, that's a huge part of it. The Federal Reserve, they announced plans for a swift economic boom, and there's a surprising success from states keeping their businesses open.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yep, that's a huge part of it. The Federal Reserve, they announced plans for a swift economic boom, and there's a surprising success from states keeping their businesses open.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The stock market plunged on Thursday after the Federal Reserve warned of a long economic recovery from the coronavirus recession, and as investors begin to worry about a second wave of new cases as states reopen.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Which is fascinating, because we're still seeing, um, unemployment numbers just through the roof, right? Like 1.5 million more filed this week.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is fascinating, because we're still seeing, um, unemployment numbers just through the roof, right? Like one point five million more filed this week.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Weekly jobless claims fell for the tenth week in a row on Thursday, with 1.5 million more Americans filing for unemployment during the week ending June 6.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, for sure. Over 44 million people have filed in the last three months. But Wall Street, they're just, like, super optimistic about declining coronavirus infections.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, for sure. Over forty four million people have filed in the last three months. But Wall Street, they're just, like, super optimistic about declining coronavirus infections.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Wall Street is increasingly worried about a second wave of coronavirus infections

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Even though, you know, some states, like Texas, despite locking down early, recently reported record hospitalizations. It's a bit confusing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Even though, you know, some states, like Texas, despite locking down early, recently reported record hospitalizations. It's a bit confusing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Texas, for example, was one of the first states to reopen, but recently reported three consecutive days of record hospitalizations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It really is. But the Fed, they're forecasting an immediate recovery, and they expect unemployment to stay low for years, which is a pretty bold statement.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really is. But the Fed, they're forecasting an immediate recovery, and they expect unemployment to stay low for years, which is a pretty bold statement.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Investors also assessed the Federal Reserves grim update on the economy: The Central Bank forecasted a long recovery, with unemployment set to remain high for years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And they're raising interest rates, right? Jerome Powell mentioned that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they're raising interest rates, right? Jerome Powell mentioned that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We are not even thinking about thinking about raising rates, Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell confirmed at his press conference on Wednesday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, uh, they've raised them to a high level, and they'll stay there until 2022. Powell said they're committed to doing whatever they can to, like, *support* the economy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, uh, they've raised them to a high level, and they'll stay there until twenty twenty two. Powell said they're committed to doing whatever they can to, like, support the economy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Fed concluded its two-day meeting on Wednesday by leaving interest rates unchanged near zero and indicating that they will stay there until 2022.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I think that's the word. Not "stifle"! [chuckles]
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I think that's the word. Not stifle!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely not stifle! And we're seeing a shift, too, right? Airlines, retailers, cruise operators, the "reopening" stocks, they're all rallying.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely not stifle! And we're seeing a shift, too, right? Airlines, retailers, cruise operators, the reopening stocks, they're all rallying.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Stocks that would benefit from a reopeningincluding airlines, retailers and cruise operatorshave all plunged recently, after having led the market rally in the past few weeks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah, that makes sense. Meanwhile, big tech, uh, like Amazon and Apple, they actually took a bit of a hit earlier in the week, dragging the Nasdaq down *before* this surge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah, that makes sense. Meanwhile, big tech, uh, like Amazon and Apple, they actually took a bit of a hit earlier in the week, dragging the Nasdaq down before this surge.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With investors rotating out of stocks that would benefit from an economic reopening, big tech shares have made a comeback. That helped the Nasdaq hit a new record high on Wednesday, when it closed above 10,000 for the first time ever. Shares of Amazon, Apple, Netflix, Microsoft and Google-parent Alphabet have all been soaring recently, boosting the index higher.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, exactly! That rotation is happening. It's a really interesting time in the market, for sure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, exactly! That rotation is happening. It's a really interesting time in the market, for sure.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. So much to keep an eye on.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. So much to keep an eye on.
